Computational GridÔÉÅ

Lets suppose we have a system of \(n\) equations which define our system. We want to generate \(m\) (independent) paths for each state. Because we have processes our paths are time-dependent, defined in some time window range \([t_{start},t_{end}]\). Because we simulate Discrete stochastic processes, the interval \([t_{start},t_{end}]\) is divided into \(k\) subintervals.

The parameters \(n,m,k\) are inputs (among others) for the Monte Carlo engine.

  • \(n\) number of equations

  • \(m\) number of paths

  • \(k\) number of time points

Thus, during a single Monte Carlo simulation the engine will need to compute \(n \cdot m \cdot k\) values.

Note

The GPU card NVIDIA GeForce RTX 2060 Super is capable of computing \(n \cdot m \cdot k = 10^{10}\) values in seconds.
